title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for teacher stabilization to prevent layoffs and create jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves a small percentage of funds for assistance to outlying areas and the Secretary of the Interior for activities consistent with the title. The Secretary reserves funds for administration and oversight of the title, including program evaluation. The award amount for each State is determined based on the population of individuals aged 5 through 17 living in the State compared to other States. The Secretary allocates funds to States based on their population of individuals aged 5 through 17. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary reallocates the funds to other States using a specific formula. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. The chief executive of a State must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of the enactment of the Act to seek a grant under this title. The application should include information required by the Secretary, with an assurance that the State will maintain support for education at a certain level for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The State must maintain support for education at a certain level for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The chief executive of a State desiring not to receive a grant under this title must submit a letter to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment explaining their decision. The Secretary may waive the requirement for a State to provide assurance under certain circumstances, such as natural disasters or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. Each State receiving a grant under this title must reserve a portion of the funds for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining grant funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies to support early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education. The State receiving a grant must distribute funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios. 60% of the remaining grant funds are allocated based on enrollment, while 40% is distributed for other educational purposes. The State must allocate 40 percent of remaining grant funds to local educational agencies based on their funding received under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies within 100 days. Prohibitions include not using funds for rainy-day funds or debt reduction. The State must allocate grant funds to local educational agencies within 100 days, with prohibitions on using funds for rainy-day funds or debt reduction. Grant funds should not supplant State funds in a way that reduces State debt obligations. SEC. 105. Local educational agency subgrants must be used for retaining, recalling, or hiring employees for educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106. Early learning programs. SEC. 106. Early learning programs funded under this title must use the funds for retaining, recalling, or hiring early childhood educators to provide services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107. REPORTING.

States receiving grants must report on fund usage and job support by September 30 of 2013 and 2014.

SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS.

Defines key terms such as "local educational agency", "outlying area", "State educational agency", and "State-funded early learning program". SEC. 109. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $30,000,000,000 authorized for grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013.

TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION
SEC. 201. PURPOSE. Funds provided to States and localities to prevent layoffs and create jobs for law enforcement officers and firefighters.
SEC. 202. FIREFIGHTER GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. The Secretary may waive certain requirements in the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act. Additional funds are authorized for grants under the Act. The Prevention and Control Act of 1974 authorizes $1 billion to be appropriated for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with $2 million reserved for administrative costs by the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Law Enforcement Officer Grant Program. These grants are not subject to certain sections of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. Additional funds may be appropriated for these grants. The Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 authorizes $4 billion for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with $8 million reserved for administrative costs each year.
